body.head: Erie, Pennslyvania March 16, 1948
body.p: Assistant to the President in charge of Extension
State College, Pennslyvania
Subject: Request for consideration of an Erie Undergraduate Center
Dear Mr. Keller

Some preliminary consideration has been given, we believe, to the advisability of establishing an undergraduate center of Pennsylvania State College at Erie, Pennsylvania. Since the matter was first discussed, a number of developments have taken place which indicate the desirability of concisely restating our reasons for presenting our request, and to provide you with a statement of all the facts which will be of value in giving it your earnest consideration.
Evidence of Need:
It is realized that evidence of the need of primary importance. Erie is not only growing rapidly in population at present, but it is also expected to continue to grow for several years.

One principle reason for this conviction is due to the fact that the General Electric Company, which is the largest local employer, has greatly expanded its facilities to employ many more people on a regular basis. Before World War II, it noramlly employed about 6000. This employment increased to a peak of 11,000 during the war. It numbers about 18,000 at present, which is three times as large as before the war, and this employment is expected to settle dowm to a figure of around 16,000. Conservative estimates indicate that this increase will bring about a growth of around 50,000 in population in the next few years, over and above the presently esti- mated mumber of 125,000. This will include the families of these employees, the butchers, bakers, store clerks, professional people and others which go to comprise all community services.

Being very largely an industrial community, with over 100 diversified industries, surrounded by rich farm lands, it is self-evident that educational facilities leading to degrees in sciences, engineering and agriculture are of considerable importance.

To further check the evidance of definite need, a questionnaire was prepared a year ago, with the counsel and assistance of Mr. David B. Pugh, of Pennsylvanta State College, to determine the number of high school undergraduates who would be interested in availing themselves of the first two years of college courses if an Undergraduate Center of Pennsylvania State College were to be established here. All were requested to discuss the questions asked with their parents, and turn in their replies.

These were the questions: 1.) Do you plan to go to college? (Yes or no); 2.) Have you applied for enrollment in any college? (Yes or no); 3.) Have you been accepted? (Yes or no); 4.) Would you consider entering a college to be established in Erie and operated by the Pennsylvania State College? (Yes or no). Name and address were optional.
A total of 2800 such questionnaires were distributed to potential enrollees in Erie High Schools through the cooperation of the School Administrative Office, their report of the results indicated:-
1. 173 students plan to go to college but were not interested in a Pennsylvania State College branch in Erie.
2. 245 do not plan to go to college but would be interested if there were a Pennsylvania State College branch in Erie.
3. 477 are going to college and are interestod in a Pennsylvania State College branch in Erie.

The above would indicate that there are a very substantial number of potential enrollees who would be directly benefitted through the establishment of an Undergraduate Center here. In addition, many employees of local industries will definitely be interested in accredited courses offered. Were these figures to be discounted 50% at the present time, it would still be conclusive evidence of definite interest and support of such a project. Since school enrollments are increasing, it can be safely assumed that future interest will be even greater than indicated at present.

While discussing need in Erie, it should also be pointed out that there is definite need for coeducational facilities which would permit women to enroll in preparation for the steadily increasing number of technical fields now open to women.
Facilities to house an Undergraduate Center:

Since from a practical standpoint, it would seem wiser to locate and rent existing facilities until the success of the center were assured, the desirability of establishing such a Center in Erie was presented to the members of the Erie School Board at their meeting held January 15, 1940, and suggesting that a school building not presently needed for classroom work be made available, on a temporary basis. Funds for necessary rearrangement of, and improvenent in, the building were assured, so as to cause the Board no expense. At their next regular monthly meeting, the proposal was violently opposed by representatives of Gannon College of Erie, who incorrectly stated that six area colleges objected. These were listed as:- Gannon College, Mercyhurst College, Villa Maria College, Polish Alliance College, Edinboro State Teachers College, and Allegheny College.

Neither Edinboro nor Allegheny were authorized to comment officially, and have since repudiated the misleading statements made concerning their attitude towards the proposal. It is indeed unfortunate that data secured some time ago for an entirely different purpose was used to give the impression that there is no present need for high caliber instruction facilities in the Erie Community, in addition to the already excellent liberal arts courses being offered.

The request for a school butlding was denied, on the basis that the School Board required the use of the building for storage purposes; it would entail great expense to move the furniture; and that the Board is only interested in educational matters affecting grade school and high school pupils. This possibility is therefore definitely ruled out in the City of Erie for the present.

However, many civic groups, such as the Business and Professional Women's Club, the League of Women Voters, the Erie City Council of P.T.A., as well as many groups of interested citizens have evidenced a growing conviction of the need, in writing, and have insisted that the project be actively pursued in spite of the objections raised by those interested in preserving a monopoly of existing facilities.

Therefore, as the result of further investigation, we now have the assurance of unanimous cooperation from the School Board of a township adjacent to Erie, who have offered the free use of an area of several acres alongside a large High School; the use of their auditorium, gymnasium, and procurement facilities; and in case of temporary need while construction is being completed, the use of classroom facilities after 3:30 P.M.

It is confidently known that the Erie Community will be able to raise the funds necessary to construct a modest building to accommodate approximately 400 students, laboratory facilities, library, and offices. This building would be erected on the site offered, and would be considered a decided asset to the community.
Summary:

1. The need for the facilities offered by a coeducational Undergraduate Center such as now provided in other communities of the State by the Pennsylvania State College, has definitely been established in the Erie Community.
2. Adequate facilities will be provided in a receptive community adjacent to Erie, and reached by City bus service.
3. Early consideration on the part of those in charge of Extension--Pennsylvania State College--is most earnestly requested towards the establishment of an Undergraduate Center in the Erie Community,

Active work in designing the facilities, or raising necessary funds is held in abeyance pending word from Pennsylvania State College. It is our sincere hope that favorable consideration will be given and that advice to proceed may be received in time to complete the project ready for enrollments in September 1948.
Respectfully,
R. C. Reed
R. C. Reed, Acting Chairman
Supervisor of Personnel, General Electric Co.
